thread.title: When your succulent just won't stop growing
thread.title_full: When your succulent just won't stop growing

author: Kirsty McMurray
title: When your succulent just won't stop growing
text:
When your succulent just won't stop growing KIRSTY MCMURRAY Last updated 11:54, February 22 2017 Gaye Mullin 
Gaye Mullin's agave geminiflora is so big it's difficult to photograph. 
The enormously tall plant in Gaye Mullin's garden isn't a beanstalk, but Jack probably would've been able to climb it. 
The branchless spike of the succulent, an Agave Geminiflora, is growing at least 15 centimetres a day and has so far reached about five metres in height. 
"It's getting bigger by the day," Mullin said. "And it's sturdy. It's like a tree trunk." Gaye Mullin 
Gaye Mullin from Waitara and her Agave Geminiflora which she reckons has grown to about 15ft. 
The plant is a native of Mexico, but Mullin bought hers from the Ellerslie Garden Show when it was still held in Auckland in 2008. 
READ MORE: 
She had no idea what she was in for, but thought the plant's long, thin, flexible leaves would make a pretty addition to her floral art arrangements. Gaye Mullin 
Mullin says she doesn't think it's done growing yet. 
"I just liked the look of it. It's sort of got a bit of rhythm to it." 
She planted it in her half-acre garden on Princess St in Waitara in North Taranaki, and enjoyed using it in her art. 
She even gave some of it to a floral art friend who had won an award with it, she said. Gaye Mullin 
The stalk sprung from within this spiky ball of leaves. 
It did nothing other than that for a few years. 
"It just sat there. It's quite attractive," Mullin said. 
But three weeks ago, she noticed a stalk had sprung from the middle of the spiky ball of leaves. 
"I thought it was going to have babies but then it just grew and grew." 
"I've never seen anything like it. 
"I thought we were going to be taken over." 
She said she had done some research and discovered the succulent was preparing to flower. 
"It only flowers once in its life, and then I assume it dies." 
It might be a little premature too - they usually flower when they reach maturity 10-15 years after being planted. 
The Agave Geminiflora is also known as the Twin Flowered Agave and its flowers are tiny, yellow and grow from the stalk in pairs. 
But Mullin's isn't flowering yet. 
"It's growing at a rapid rate and I think it's got more to go yet," she said.
